deviation from the norm of height with respect to that which is expected according to age and gender norms .
multicystic dysplasia of the kidney is characterized by multiple cysts of varying size in the kidney and the absence of a normal pelvicaliceal system .
the pattern in which a particular genetic trait or disorder is passed from one generation to the next .
a mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on one of the autosomes  ( i .e . ,  the human chromosomes 1 - 22 )  in which a trait manifests in heterozygotes .
a mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on one of the autosomes  ( i .e . ,  the human chromosomes 1 - 22 )  in which a trait manifests in individuals with two pathogenic alleles ,  either homozygotes  ( two copies of the same mutant allele )  or compound heterozygotes  ( whereby each copy of a gene has a distinct mutant allele )  .

a fold of skin starting at or just below the medial aspect of the lower lid and arching upward to cover ,  extend in front of and lateral to the medial canthus .
apparent optic disc swelling in the absence of increased intracranial pressure .
an abnormality in the process of focusing of light by the eye in order to produce a sharp image on the retina .
an abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects in the distance clearly ,  while objects nearby appear blurry .
separation of the inner layers of the retina  ( neural retina )  from the pigment epithelium .
reduced ability to move the eye in the direction of the nose .
a pale yellow discoloration of the optic disk  ( the area of the optic nerve head in the retina )  .
paralysis of the external ocular muscles .
an abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects nearby clearly ,  while objects in the distance appear blurry .
a nonspecific term denoting degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium and / or retinal photoreceptor cells .
any deviation from the normal motor coordination of the eyes that allows for bilateral fixation on a single object .
lack of any response to stimulation upon electroretinography .
an anomaly in the ability to discriminate between or recognize colors .
difficulty distinguishing between yellow and blue ,  possible related to dysfunction of the s photopigment .
an abnormality of the uvea ,  the vascular layer of the eyeball .
inflammation of one or all portions of the uveal tract .
an abnormal white reflection from the pupil rather than the usual black reflection .
retinal dystrophy is an abnormality of the retina associated with a hereditary process .
diffusely large eye  ( with megalocornea )  associated with glaucoma .
a congenital malformation of the anterior segment characterized by iridicorneal malformation ,  glaucoma ,  iris stroma hypoplasia ,  posterior embryotoxon ,  and corneal opacities .
lack of eyelashes .
a cone - shaped deformity of the cornea characterized by the presence of corneal distortion secondary to thinning of the apex .
a developmental disorder of the lacrimal drainage system that most often affects the lacrimal ostium and resulting in non - opening of the nasolacrimal duct .
a form of strabismus with one or both eyes turned inward  ( 'crossed' )  to a relatively severe degree ,  usually defined as 10 diopters or more .
absence of a region of the retina ,  retinal pigment epithelium ,  and choroid .
a developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one or both eyes .
an abnormality of eye movement characterized by impairment of fast  ( saccadic )  eye movements .
saccadic undershoot ,  i .e . ,  a saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object .
loss of visual acuity  ( implying that vision was better at a certain timepoint in life )  .
hemorrhage occurring within the retina .
increased density / number and / or increased diameter of eyebrow hairs .
a regional and pathological increase of the light detection threshold in any region of the visual field surrounded by a field of normal or relatively well - preserved vision .
a scotoma  ( area of diminished vision within the visual field )  located between the central point of fixation and the blind spot with a roughly horizontal oval shape .
a form of strabismus with one or both eyes deviated outward .
blockage of the lacrimal duct .
an abnormality of the retina characterized by pigment deposition .
a fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures .
the palpebral fissure inclination is more than two standard deviations above the mean for age  ( objective )  ;  or ,  the inclination of the palpebral fissure is greater than typical for age .
an abnormality of the cornea characterized by the deposition of calcium in a band across the central cornea ,  leading to decreased vision ,  foreign body sensation ,  and ocular irritation .
reduced depth of the orbits associated with prominent - appearing ocular globes .
abnormality of the optic nerve .
a cleft of the optic nerve that extends inferiorly .
a developmental defect characterized by a cleft of some portion of the eye or ocular adnexa .
initial bilateral ptosis followed by limitation of eye movements in all directions and slowing of saccades .
an abnormality of the sclera .
an abnormal bluish coloration of the sclera .
abnormality of the anterior chamber ,  which is the space in the eye that is behind the cornea and in front of the iris .
reduced depth of the anterior chamber ,  i .e . ,  the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is decreased .
ophthalmoplegia is a paralysis or weakness of one or more of the muscles that control eye movement .
an abnormality of the ear .
an anomaly in the placement or shape of the hairline  ( trichion )  on the forehead ,  that is ,  the border between skin on the forehead that has head hair and that does not .
an anomaly of the pharynx ,  i .e . ,  of the tubular structure extending from the base of the skull superiorly to the esophageal inlet inferiorly .
interpupillary distance less than 2 sd below the mean  ( alternatively ,  the appearance of an decreased interpupillary distance or closely spaced eyes )  .
paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles that are responsible for eye movements .
an area of depressed vision located at the point of fixation and that interferes with central vision .
a supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a particular direction as a result of cerebral impairment .
an abnormality of the region situated around the orbit of the eye .
a nonspecific term denoting degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium and / or retinal photoreceptor cells of the macula lutea .
underdevelopment of the optic nerve .
any structural abnormality of the choroid .
a coloboma of the iris .
excessive sensitivity to light with the sensation of discomfort or pain in the eyes due to exposure to bright light .
an abnormality of the nasolacrimal drainage system ,  which serves as a conduit for tear flow from the external eye to the nasal cavity .
an abnormality of the pupil .
abnormal  ( non - physiological )  constriction of the pupil .
an abnormality of eye movement characterized by impaired smooth - pursuit eye movements .
blindness is the condition of lacking visual perception defined as visual perception below 3 / 60 and / or a visual field of no greater than 10 degress in radius around central fixation .
reduced ability to turn the eyes inward in order to focus on a nearby object .
inflammation of the nasolacrimal sac .
an abnormal inversion  ( turning inward )  of the eyelid  ( usually the lower )  towards the globe .
lack of sharpness of vision resulting in the inability to see fine detail .
a vertical gaze palsy with inability to direct the gaze of the eyes downwards .
a short discontinuity of the margin of the lower or upper eyelid .
a posterior embryotoxon is the presence of a prominent and anteriorly displaced line of schwalbe .
increase in periorbital soft tissue .
the presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal artery .
abnormality of tear production .
abnormally decreased lacrimation ,  that is ,  reduced ability to produce tears .
an impaired ability of the eye to move in the outward direction  ( towards the side of the head )  .
a markedly blue coloration of the iris .
a short discontinuity of the margin of the upper eyelid .
distance between medial and lateral canthi is more than two standard deviations above the mean for age  ( objective )  ;  or ,  apparently increased length of the palpebral fissures .
rhythmic ,  involuntary oscillations of one or both eyes related to abnormality in fixation ,  conjugate gaze ,  or vestibular mechanisms .
nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left .
the controller signal for saccadic eye movements has two components: the pulse that moves the eye rapidly from one point to the next ,  and the step that holds the eye in the new position .
difficulty with discriminating red and green hues .
a focal dystonia that affects the muscles of the eyelids and brow ,  associated with involuntary recurrent spasm of both eyelids .
reduced visual acuity that is uncorrectable by lenses in the absence of detectable anatomic defects in the eye or visual pathways .
a congenital anomaly in which a part or the whole of the cornea acquires the characteristics of sclera ,  resulting in clouding of the cornea .
atrophy of the optic nerve .
an anomaly of visually evoked potentials  ( vep )  ,  which are electrical potentials ,  initiated by brief visual stimuli ,  which are recorded from the scalp overlying the visual cortex .
diplopia is a condition in which a single object is perceived as two images ,  it is also known as double vision .
a short discontinuity of the margin of the lower eyelid .
decreased density / number of eyelashes .
descreased amplitude of eletrical response upon electroretinography .
an outward turning  ( eversion )  or rotation of the eyelid margin .
ocular motor apraxia is a deficiency in voluntary ,  horizontal ,  lateral ,  fast eye movements  ( saccades )  with retention of slow pursuit movements .
a form of anterior segment dysgenesis in which abnormal cleavage of the anterior chamber occurs .
a creamy appearance of the retinal blood vessels that occurs when the concentration of lipids in the blood are extremely increased ,  with pale pink to milky white retinal vessels and altered pale reflexes from choroidal vasculature .
inability to see well at night or in poor light .
meeting of the medial eyebrows in the midline .
nystagmus consisting of horizontal to - and - fro eye movements .
atrophy of the eyeball with blindness and decreased intraocular pressure due to end - stage intraocular disease .
a developmental anomaly characterized by a reduced number of teeth ,  whereby up to 6 teeth are missing .
caries is a multifactorial bacterial infection affecting the structure of the tooth .
the congenital absence of all teeth .
increased size of the maxillary central secondary incisor tooth .
an abnormality of the incisor tooth .
a developmental anomaly characterized by a reduced number of teeth ,  whereby more than 6 teeth are missing .
overlapping teeth within an alveolar ridge .
increased volume of dental pulp of permanent molar .
delayed tooth eruption affecting the primary dentition .
an abnormality of the dental enamel .
a grey discoloration of the dental enamel .
delayed tooth eruption ,  which can be defined as tooth eruption more than 2 sd beyond the mean eruption age .
developmental hypoplasia of teeth .
increased spaces  ( diastemata )  between most of the teeth in the same dental arch .
dental malocclusion refers to an abnormality of the occlusion ,  or alignment ,  of the teeth and the way the upper and lower teeth fit together ,  resulting in overcrowding of teeth or in abnormal bite patterns .
agenesis of one or more maxillary lateral incisor ,  comprising the maxillary lateral primary incisor and maxillary lateral secondary incisor .
decreased size of the teeth ,  which can be defined as a mesiodistal tooth diameter  ( width )  more than 2 sd below mean .
abnormal alignment ,  positioning ,  or spacing of the teeth ,  i .e . ,  misaligned teeth .
a type of dental dysplasia occurring in dentinogenesis imperfecta in which the pulp chambers are enlarged and there is a reduced amount of coronal dentin .
erupted tooth or teeth at birth .
delayed tooth eruption affecting the secondary dentition .
an abnormal conical form of the teeth ,  that is ,  a tooth whose sides converge or taper together incisally .
increased space between two adjacent teeth in the same dental arch .
radiolucency  ( reflecting a reduction in the bony substance )  around the apex  ( the tip of the dental root )  .
developmental dysplasia of dentin .
inflammation of the periodontium .
a developmental dysplasia of the dental enamel .
the presence of one or more embedded tooth germs which have failed to erupt .
an abnormality of the nervous system .
an abnormality of mental functioning including various affective ,  behavioural ,  cognitive and perceptual abnormalities .
a condition characterized by changes of personality and thought patterns often accompanied by hallucinations and delusional beliefs .
a tendency or compulsion to examine objects by mouth .
a state of unease characterized by diffuse motor activity or motion subject to limited control ,  nonproductive or disorganized behavior ,  and subjective distress .
unstable emotional experiences and frequent mood changes ;  emotions that are easily aroused ,  intense ,  and / or out of proportion to events and circumstances .
a state of exceeding restlessness and excessive motor activity associated with mental distress or a feeling of inner tension .
frequent feelings of being down ,  miserable ,  and / or hopeless ;  difficulty recovering from such moods ;  pessimism about the future ;  pervasive shame ;  feeling of inferior self - worth ;  thoughts of suicide and suicidal behavior .
autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction and communication ,  and by restricted and repetitive behavior .
aggressive behavior can denote verbal aggression ,  physical aggression against objects ,  physical aggression against people ,  and may also include aggression towards oneself .
an exaggeration of emotional affects such as laughing crying ,  or yawning beyond what the person feels .
recurrent obsessions or compulsions that are severe enough to be time consuming  ( i .e . ,  they take more than 1 hour a day )  or cause marked distress or significant impairment  ( dsm - iv )  .
behavior characterized by an abnormal limitation to few interests and activities .
a loss of global cognitive ability of sufficient amount to interfere with normal social or occupational function .
persistent deficits in social interaction and communication and interaction as well as a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest as well as repetitive patterns of behavior .
a stereotypy is a repetitive ,  simple movement that can be voluntarily suppressed .
a lack of restraint manifested in several ways ,  including disregard for social conventions ,  impulsivity ,  and poor risk assessment .
difficulty in social interactions related to an impairment of characteristics such as eye contact ,  smiling ,  appropriate facial expressions ,  and body postures and characterized by difficulty in forming peer relationships and forming friendships .
reduced attention span characterized by distractibility and impulsivity but not necessarily satisfying the diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder .
perceptions in a conscious and awake state in the absence of external stimuli which have qualities of real perception ,  in that they are vivid ,  substantial ,  and located in external objective space .
intense feelings of nervousness ,  tenseness ,  or panic ,  often in reaction to interpersonal stresses ;  worry about the negative effects of past unpleasant experiences and future negative possibilities ;  feeling fearful ,  apprehensive ,  or threatened by uncertainty ;  fears of falling apart or losing control .
recurrent attacks of severe anxiety ,  whose occurence is not restricted to any particular situation or set of circumstances and is therefore unpredictable .
primitive reflexes traditionally held to be a sign of disorders that affect the frontal lobes .
the feeling of frustration can be defined as an emotional reaction that occurs if a desired goal is not achieved .
a reduction in goal - directed behavior ,  that is ,  motivation ,  the determinant of behavior and adaptation that allows individuals to get started ,  be energized to perform a sustained and directed action .
a belief that is pathological and is held despite evidence to the contrary .
a degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age .
an abnormal shift in patterns of thinking ,  acting ,  or feeling .
hyperactivity is a state of constantly being unusually or abnormally active ,  including in situations in which it is not appropriate .
a type of anxiety disorder characterized by avoidance of public places ,  especially where crowds gather .
reduced ability to use nonverbal behavior for communication ,  such as eye - to - eye gaze ,  facial expression ,  body posture ,  and gestures .
a structural abnormality of the peripheral nervous system ,  which is composed of the nerves that lead to or branch off from the central nervous system .
a reduction in the speed at which electrical signals propagate along the axon of a neuron .
peripheral neuropathy affecting the sensory nerves .
progressive deterioration of peripheral axons .
any abnormality of the thorax  ( the region of the body formed by the sternum ,  the thoracic vertebrae and the ribs )  .
an anomaly of the sternum ,  also known as the breastbone .
a defect of the chest wall characterized by a depression of the sternum ,  giving the chest  (  \ "pectus \ " )  a caved - in  (  \ "excavatum \ " )  appearance .
a deformity of the chest caused by overgrowth of the ribs and characterized by protrusion of the sternum .
an abnormality of the breast .
abnormal development of large mammary glands in males resulting in breast enlargement .
an anomaly of the rib .
reduced rib length .
reduced width of the chest from side to side ,  associated with a reduced distance from the sternal notch to the tip of the shoulder .
any abnormality of the diaphragm ,  the sheet of skeletal muscle that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity .
the presence of a hernia of the diaphragm present at birth .
abnormality of the thymus ,  an organ located in the upper anterior portion of the chest cavity just behind the sternum and whose main function is to provide an environment for t lymphocyte maturation .
underdevelopment of the thymus .
any abnormality of the scapula ,  also known as the shoulder blade .
the presence of calculi  ( stones )  in the kidneys .
the presence of blood in the urine .
the presence of uric acid - containing calculi  ( stones )  in the kidneys .

reduced count of spermatozoa in the semen ,  defined as a sperm count below 20 million per milliliter semen .

cysts of the cortex of the kidney .

lack of the ability to control the urinary bladder leading to involuntary urination at an age where control of the bladder should already be possible .
a severe form of hypospadias in which the urethral opening is located at the junction of the penis and scrotum .
congenital absence of the normal opening of a structure of the urinary tract .
an anomaly of the adnexa ,  uterus ,  and vagina  ( in female )  or seminal tract and prostate  ( in male )  .
the presence of a bicornuate uterus .
reduced function of the gonads  ( testes in males or ovaries in females )  associated with excess pituitary gonadotropin secretion and resulting in delayed sexual development and growth delay .
an abnormality of the tricarboxylic acid cycle .
difficulty in looking at another person in the eye .
an abnormality of the endocrine system .
a group of abnormalities characterized by hyperglycemia and glucose intolerance .
an abnormality of the thyroid gland .
deficiency of thyroid hormone .
the presence of chronic increased pressure in the systemic arterial system .
passing the age when puberty normally occurs with no physical or hormonal signs of the onset of puberty .
insufficient production of growth hormone ,  which is produced by the anterior pituitary gland .
an increased concentration of insulin combined with a decreased concentration of glucose in the blood .
the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before a normal age .
an abnormality of the parathyroid gland .
a condition caused by a deficiency of parathyroid hormone characterized by hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia .
a condition of reduced function of the anterior pituitary gland characterized by decreased secretion of one or more of the pituitary hormones growth hormone ,  thyroid - stimulating hormone ,  adrenocorticotropic hormone ,  prolactin ,  luteinizing hormone ,  and follicle - stimulating hormone .
a type of diabetes mellitus related not to lack of insulin but rather to lack of response to insulin on the part of the target tissues of insulin such as muscle ,  fat ,  and liver cells .
a type of hypothyroidism that results from a defect in the thyroid gland .
abnormality of the adrenal glands ,  i .e . ,  of the endocrine glands located at the top of the kindneys .
developmental hypoplasia of the adrenal glands .
an abnormality of thyroid physiology characterized by excessive secretion of the thyroid hormones thyroxine  ( i .e . ,  t4 )  and / or 3 , 3' , 5 - triiodo - l - thyronine zwitterion  ( i .e . ,  triiodothyronine or t3 )  .
overproduction of gonadotropins  ( fsh ,  lh )  by the anterior pituitary gland .
a type of reduced stature with normal proportions related to dysfunction of the pituitary gland related to either an isolated defect in the secretion of growth hormone or to panhypopituitarism ,  i .e . ,  a deficit of all the anterior pituitary hormones .
adrenogenital syndrome is also known as congenital adrenal hyperplasia ,  which results from disorders of steroid hormone production in the adrenal glands leading to a deficiency of cortisol .
an abnormally increased activity of the renin - angiotensin system ,  causing hypertension by a combination of volume excess and vasoconstrictor mechanisms .
an increased concentration of insulin in the blood .
excessive production of parathyroid hormone  ( pth )  by the parathyroid glands .
acromegaly is a condition resulting from overproduction of growth hormone by the pituitary gland in persons with closed epiphyses ,  and consists chiefly in the enlargement of the distal parts of the body .
insufficient production of steroid hormones  ( primarily cortisol )  by the adrenal glands .
an abnormality of the renin - angiotensin system .
an increased level of renin in the blood .
a type of hypothyroidism with congenital onset .
a condition characterized by resistance to the action of parathyroid hormone ,  in which there is hypocalcemia ,  hyperphosphatemia ,  and  ( appropriately )  high levels of parathyroid hormone .
an enlargement of the thyroid gland .
the presence of a adenoma of the thyroid gland .
increased resistance towards insulin ,  that is ,  diminished effectiveness of insulin in reducing blood glucose levels .
abnormally high variation in the amount of time between periods .
overproduction of the mineralocorticoid aldosterone by the adrenal cortex .
developmental hypoplasia of the parathyroid gland .
a form of diabetes insipidus related to a failure of vasopressin  ( avp )  release from the hypothalamus .
abnormality of the pituitary gland  ( also known as hypophysis )  ,  which is an endocrine gland that protrudes from the bottom of the hypothalamus at the base of the brain .
secondary hyperparathyroidism refers to the production of higher than normal levels of parathyroid hormone in the presence of hypocalcemia .
the presence of abnormally increased levels of prolactin in the blood .
a pituitary functional deficit affecting all the anterior pituitary hormones  ( growth hormone ,  thyroid - stimulating hormone ,  follicle - stimulating hormone ,  luteinizing hormone ,  adrenocorticotropic hormone ,  and prolactin )  .
a chronic ,  autoimmune type of thyroiditis associated with hypothyroidism .
a state of excessive water intake and hypotonic  ( dilute )  polyuria .
infrequent menses  ( less than 6 per year or more than 35 days between cycles )  .
presence of only 11 pairs of ribs .
decreased inferosuperior length of the sternum .
underdeveloped scapula .
ribs with a reduced diameter .
increased width of ribs
malformation of the rib cage .
wide ,  concave rib end .
a horizontal  ( flat )  conformation of the ribs ,  the long curved bones that form the rib cage and normally progressively oblique  ( slanted )  from ribs 1 through 9 ,  then less slanted through rib 12 .
any abnormality of the clavicles  ( collar bones )  .
increased length of the clavicles .
a bifid rib refers to cleavage of the sternal end of a rib ,  usually unilateral .
abnormal outward curving  ( protuberance )  of the junction of ribs and costal cartilage .
reduced length of the clavicles .
an excessive upward convexity of the lateral clavicle .
multiple circumscribed bony excrescences located in the ribs .

complete or partial merging of adjacent ribs .

wide ,  concave anterior rib end .

a congenital skeletal deformity characterized by the elevation of one scapula  ( thus ,  one scapula is located superior to the other )  .
complete or partial merging of the posterior part of adjacent ribs .
a broad chest .
pectus excavatum  ( defect of the chest wall characterized by depression of the sternum )  affecting primarily the inferior region of the sternum .
increased width  ( cross - sectional diameter )  of the clavicles .
pectus carinatum affecting primarily the superior part of the sternum .
the presence of multiple exostoses on the scapula .
any anomaly of the costochondral junction .
abnormally increased size of the costochondral junctions ,  which are located between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages ,  which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum .
a developmental anomaly with absence of one or more ribs .
wide ,  concave posterior rib end .
the presence of a row of multiple rounded expansions  ( beadlike prominences )  at the junction of a rib and its cartilage .
an abnormality of the skeletal system .
any abnormality of the vertebral column .
a flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance between the vertebral endplates .
the bones of the skeleton undergo a series of characteristic changes in size ,  shape ,  and calcification from fetal life until puberty .
an abnormality of the skull ,  the bony framework of the head which is comprised of eight cranial and fourteen facial bones .
an abnormality of the fossa cranii posterior  ( the posterior fossa )  ,  which is made up primarily of the occipital bone and which surrounds to the foramen magnum .
radiographic evidence of articular calcification that represent calcium pyrophosphate depositions in soft tissue surrounding joints and at the insertions of tendons near joints  ( entheses / sharpey fibers )   .
abnormal thickening of the cortex of long bones .
osteopenia is a term to define bone density that is not normal but also not as low as osteoporosis .
osteoporosis is a systemic skeletal disease characterized by low bone density and microarchitectural deterioration of bone tissue with a consequent increase in bone fragility .
an abnormality of the structure or form of the diaphysis ,  i .e . ,  of the main or mid - section  ( shaft )  of a long bone .
an abnormality of one or more metaphysis ,  i .e . ,  of the somewhat wider portion of a long bone that is adjacent to the epiphyseal growth plate and grows during childhood .
underdevelopment of the ilium .
an abnormal appearance of the long bones with resemblance to a dumbbell ,  a short bar with a weight at each end .
an abnormality of the skin .
yellow pigmentation of the skin due to bilirubin ,  which in turn is the result of increased bilirubin concentration in the bloodstream .
a darkening of the skin related to an increase in melanin production and deposition .
the distal and proximal transverse palmar creases are merged into a single transverse palmar crease .
a dermatosis characterized by thickened ,  hyperpigmented plaques ,  typically on the intertriginous surfaces and neck .
cafe - au - lait spots are hyperpigmented lesions that can vary in color from light brown to dark brown with smooth borders and having a size of 1 .5 cm or more in adults and 0 .5 cm or more in children .
skin characterized by the lack of natural or normal moisture .
a cutaneous indentation resulting from tethering of the skin to underlying structures  ( bone )  of the intergluteal cleft .
bluish discoloration of the skin and mucosa due to poor circulation or inadequate oxygenation of arterial or capillary blood .
hyperkeratosis is thickening of the outer layer of the skin ,  the stratum corneum ,  which is composed of large ,  polyhedral ,  plate - like envelopes filled with keratin which are the dead cells that have migrated up from the stratum granulosum .
reduction in thickness of the skin ,  generally associated with a loss of suppleness and elasticity of the skin .
eczema is a form of dermatitis .
a reticular discoloration of the skin with cyanotic  ( reddish - blue appearing )  areas surrounding pale central areas due to dilation of capillary blood vessels and stagnation of blood within the vessels .
abnormally diminished capacity to sweat .
petechiae are pinpoint - sized reddish / purple spots ,  resembling a rash ,  that appear just under the skin or a mucous membrane when capillaries have ruptured and some superficial bleeding into the skin has happened .
ectodermal dysplasia is a group of conditions in which there is abnormal development of the skin ,  hair ,  nails ,  teeth ,  or sweat glands .
an abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin ,  or in one or more cavities of the body .
inability to sweat .
any structural abnormality of the sweat gland .
hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot .
wrinkled ,  redundant ,  inelastic and sagging skin .
a condition in which the skin can be stretched beyond normal ,  and then returns to its initial position .
abnormal excessive perspiration  ( sweating )  despite the lack of appropriate stimuli like hot and humid weather .
subjective impression of increased softness upon palpitation of the skin .
an ecchymosis  ( bruise )  refers to the skin discoloration caused by the escape of blood into the tissues from ruptured blood vessels .
purpura  ( from latin: purpura ,  meaning  \ "purple \ " )  is the appearance of red or purple discolorations on the skin that do not blanch on applying pressure .
abnormally pale skin .
abnormal thickening of the skin of the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet .
atypically scarred skin  .
a red eruption of the skin .
pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch .
the presence of multiple xanthomas  ( xanthomata )  in the skin .
an increased sensitivity of the skin to light .
bluish - grey ,  spongy nodules associated with scars over pressure points and easily traumatized areas like the elbows and knees .
a oval and round ,  colored  ( usually medium - to dark brown ,  reddish brown ,  or flesh colored )  lesion .
hemangioma ,  a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells with small endothelial spaces ,  occurring in the face .
the presence in the axillary region  ( armpit )  of an increased number of freckles ,  small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin .
hypertrichosis is increased hair growth that is abnormal in quantity or location .
any manifestation of a skin disease associated with the production of pus .
an abnormality of the pigmentation of the skin .
presence of an unusually high number of lentigines  ( singular: lentigo )  ,  which are flat ,  tan to brown oval spots .
localized fluid retention and tissue swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system .
abnormally increased hair growth referring to a male pattern of body hair  ( androgenic hair )  .
telangiectasias refer to small dilated blood vessels located near the surface of the skin or mucous membranes ,  measuring between 0 .5 and 1 millimeter in diameter .
a reduction of skin color related to a decrease in melanin production and deposition .
the presence of multiple lipomas  ( a type of benign tissue made of fatty tissue )  .
eruptive xanthomas are yellow - orange - to - red - brown papules that are often surrounded by an erythematous halo .
a vascular lesion defined histologically as one or more dilated blood vessels lying directly subepidermal and showing an epidermal proliferative reaction .
a condition in which superficial veins  ( i .e . ,  veins just under the skin )  are more conspicuous or noticable than normal .
a type of pallor that is secondary to the presence of anemia .
an abnormality of the dermatoglyphs ,  i .e . ,  an abnormality of the patterns of ridges of the skin of palm of hand .
an inflammatory exfoliative dermatosis involving nearly all of the surface of the skin .
an abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation  ( reduced or absent )  of skin ,  hair and eye  ( iris and retina )  .
raised ,  well - circumscribed areas of erythema and edema involving the dermis and epidermis .
a skin texture that is unusually soft  ( and may feel silky )  ,  and has a malleable consistency resembling that of dough .
a hemangioma is a benign tumor characterized by blood - filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells .
poikiloderma refers to a patch of skin with  ( 1 )  reticulated hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation ,   ( 2 )  wrinkling secondary to epidermal atrophy ,  and  ( 3 )  telangiectasias .
skin that splits easily with minimal injury .
the presence of subcutaneous lipoma .
absence of the distal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fingers .
a hyperpigmented circumscribed area of change in normal skin color without elevation or depression of any size .
abnormal formation of the keratinocytes of the epidermis characterized by persistence of nuclei ,  incomplete formation of keratin ,  and moistness and swelling of the keratinocytes .
redness of the skin of the face ,  caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin .
jaundice that is sometimes present ,  sometimes not .
atopic dermatitis  ( ad )  or atopic eczema is an itchy ,  inflammatory skin condition with a predilection for the skin flexures .
the presence of a cavernous hemangioma .
seborrheic dermatitis is a form of eczema which is closely related to dandruff .
a congenital vascular malformation consisting of superficial and deep dilated capillaries in the skin which produce a reddish to purplish discolouration of the skin .
increased susceptibility to erysipelas ,  as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of erysipelas ,  which is a superficial infection of the skin ,  typically involving the lymphatic system .
presence of multiple small cysts containing keratin  ( skin protein )  and presenting as tiny pearly - white bumps just under the surface of the skin .
a developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin in multiple or solitary non - inflammatory ,  well - demarcated ,  oval or circular ulcers with a diameter of about 1 to 2 cm .
a reduced ability to heal cutaneous wounds .
pterygia are 'winglike' triangular membranes occurring in the neck ,  eyes ,  knees ,  elbows ,  ankles or digits .
presence of a cutaneous membrane  ( flap )  in the armpit .
a skin condition in which there is an increase in sebum secretion by the pilosebaceous apparatus associated with open comedones  ( blackheads )  ,  closed comedones  ( whiteheads )  ,  and pustular nodules  ( papules ,  pustules ,  and cysts )  .
a large pigmented lesion measuring 5 - 15 mm in diameter with irregular ,  notched ,  and ill defined border and with color that may range from tan to dark brown to pink .
thinned ,  erythematous ,  depressed bands of atrophic skin .
the presence of multiple cutaneous neurofibromas .
intermittent episodes of abnormally increased perspiration .
patchy and irregular skin pigmentation .
laminar thickening of skin .
thin  ( atrophic )  and wide scars .
scars that form a depression compared to the level of the surrounding skin because of damage to the collagen ,  fat or other tissues below the skin .
an abnormality of the biliary tree .
hard ,  pebble - like deposits that form within the gallbladder .
the presence of inflammatory changes in the gallbladder .
dislocation or malposition of the crystalline lens of the eye .
a hazy ,  grayish - white ring about 2 mm in width located close to but separated from the limbus  ( the corneoscleral junction )  .
papilledema refers to edema  ( swelling )  of the optic disc secondary to any factor which increases cerebral spinal fluid pressure .
glaucoma which forms during the early years of a child's life is called developmental or congenital glaucoma .
the presence of whitish spots in a ring - like arrangement at the periphery of the iris .
loss of iris tissue  ( atrophy ) 
diffusely large eye  ( with megalocornea )  without glaucoma .
no identifiable superior and / or inferior lacrimal punctum .
the presence of developmental dysplasia of the optic nerve .
a type of anterior uveitis ,  in which there is inflammation of the iris and the ciliary body .
inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva .
dryness of the eye related to deficiency of the tear film components  ( aqueous ,  mucin ,  or lipid )  ,  lid surface abnormalities ,  or epithelial abnormalities .
any structural abnormality of the fundus of the eye .
heterochromia iridis is a difference in the color of the iris in the two eyes .
inflammation of the iris .
irregular lines in the deep retina that are typically configured in a radiating fashion and emanate from the optic disc .
a structural abnormality of the macula lutea ,  which is an oval - shaped highly pigmented yellow spot near the center of the retina .
underdevelopment of the macula lutea .

the presence of xanthomata in the skin of the eyelid .
a polar cataract that affects the posterior pole of the lens .
a congenital defect of the macula distinct from coloboma associated with optic fissure closure defects .
severe loss of visual acuity within hours or days .
a type of cataract that is not apparent at birth but that arises in childhood or adolescence .
limbus - to - limbus corneal thinning ,  often greatest in the periphery ,  with globular protrusion of the cornea .
any abnormality of the size or morphology of the cornea .
transient blurring of vision associated with the aura phase of migraine .
cryptophthalmos is a condition of total absence of eyelids and the skin of forehead is continuous with that of cheek ,  in which the eyeball is completely concealed by the skin ,  which is stretched over the orbital cavity .
inversion and rubbing of the eyelashes against the globe of the eye .
an abnormality of the cornea that is characterized by opacity of one or parts of the cornea .
partial dislocation of the lens of the eye .
an absolute or relative decrease in retinal sensitivity extending from edge  ( periphery )  of the visual field in a concentric pattern .
a polar cataract that affects the anterior pole of the lens .
the presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal arterioles .
esotropia in which either eye may be used for fixation .
a benign tumor typically found at the junction of the cornea and sclera  ( limbal epibullar dermoid )  .
severe reduction of the ability to see defined as visual acuity less than 6 / 60  ( 20 / 200 in us notation ;  0 .1 in decimal notation )  but at least 3 / 60  ( 20 / 400 in us notation ;  0 .05 in decimal notation )  .
a conical projection of the anterior or posterior surface of the lens ,  occurring as a developmental anomaly .
presence of a cyst in the region of the periorbital tissues .
fluid which has escaped from retinal blood vessels with a high concentration of lipid ,  protein ,  and cellular debris with a typically bright ,  reflective ,  white or cream colored appearance on the surface of the retina .
the presence of fine ,  branching linear opacities in bowman's layer in the central area that may spread to the periphery in the clinical course .
an abnormality of ocular smooth pursuit characterized by an impairment of the ability to track horizontally moving objects .
an abnormality of tracking eye movements in which smooth pursuit is interrupted by an abnormally high number of saccadic movements .
the presence of a vaginal septum ,  thereby creating a vaginal duplication .
an abnormality affecting one or both hands .
digits that appear disproportionately short compared to the hand / foot .

abnormally long and slender fingers  (  \ "spider fingers \ " )  .
an anomaly of a finger .
for children from birth to 4 years of age the palm width is more than 2 sd above the mean ;  for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is above the 95th centile ;  or ,  the width of the palm appears disproportionately wide for the length .

in the resting position ,  the tip of the thumb is on ,  or near ,  the palm ,  close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger .

a seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and / or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain .
cerebellar ataxia refers to ataxia due to dysfunction of the cerebellum .
muscular hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone  ( the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle )  ,  often involving reduced muscle strength .
a state of disinterestedness ,  listlessness ,  and indifference ,  resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating .
mild intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient  ( iq )  in the range of 50 - 69 .
a motor disorder characterized by a velocity - dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone ,  exaggerated  ( hyperexcitable )  tendon reflexes .

dysarthric speech is a general description referring to a neurological speech disorder characterized by poor articulation .
a state of abnormally strong desire for sleep during the daytime .
a delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child ,  including motor skills ,  speech and language ,  cognitive skills ,  and social and emotional skills .
spasticity  ( neuromuscular hypertonia )  primarily in the muscles of the legs ,  hips ,  and pelvis .

bulbar weakness  ( or bulbar palsy )  refers to bilateral impairment of function of the lower cranial nerves ix ,  x ,  xi and xii ,  which occurs due to lower motor neuron lesion either at nuclear or fascicular level in the medulla or from bilateral lesions of the lower cranial nerves outside the brain - stem .

sudden impairment of blood flow to a part of the brain due to occlusion or rupture of an artery to the brain .
encephalopathy is a term that means brain disease ,  damage ,  or malfunction .
characteristic neurologic anomaly resulting form degeneration of dopamine - generating cells in the substantia nigra ,  a region of the midbrain ,  characterized clinically by shaking ,  rigidity ,  slowness of movement and difficulty with walking and gait .
pachygyria is a malformation of cortical development with abnormally wide gyri with sulci 1 , 5 - 3 cm apart and abnormally thick cortex measuring more than 5 mm  ( radiological definition )  .
sustained involuntary muscle contractions that produce twisting and repetitive movements of the body .

any abnormality of the cardiovascular system .
any structural anomaly of the heart .
a hole between the two bottom chambers  ( ventricles )  of the heart .
atrial septal defect  ( asd )  is a congenital abnormality of the interatrial septum that enables blood flow between the left and right atria via the interatrial septum .
any structural anomaly of the mitral valve .
one or both of the leaflets  ( cusps )  of the mitral valve bulges back into the left atrium upon contraction of the left ventricle .
the presence of an abnormality of cardiac function that is responsible for the failure of the heart to pump blood at a rate that is commensurate with the needs of the tissues or a state in which abnormally elevated filling pressures are required for the heart to do so .
a congenital cardiac malformation comprising pulmonary stenosis ,  overriding aorta ,  ventricular septum defect ,  and right ventricular hypertrophy .
a structural anomaly of the muscle layer of the heart wall .
a myocardial disorder in which the heart muscle is structurally and functionally abnormal ,  in the absence of coronary artery disease ,  hypertension ,  valvular disease and congenital heart disease sufficient to cause the observed myocardial abnormality .
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy  ( hcm )  is defined by the presence of increased ventricular wall thickness or mass in the absence of loading conditions  ( hypertension ,  valve disease )  sufficient to cause the observed abnormality .
increased size of the heart .
any structural abnormality of the pulmonary valve .
a narrowing of the right ventricular outflow tract that can occur at the pulmonary valve  ( valvular stenosis )  or just below the pulmonary valve  ( infundibular stenosis )  .
in utero ,  the ductus arteriosus  ( da )  serves to divert ventricular output away from the lungs and toward the placenta by connecting the main pulmonary artery to the descending aorta .
dilated cardiomyopathy  ( dcm )  is defined by the presence of left ventricular dilatation and left ventricular systolic dysfunction in the absence of abnormal loading conditions  ( hypertension ,  valve disease )  or coronary artery disease sufficient to cause global systolic impairment .
the heart suddenly and unexpectedly stops beating resulting in death within a short time period  ( generally within 1 h of symptom onset )  .
any abnormality of the aortic valve .
the presence of an aortic valve with two instead of the normal three cusps  ( flaps )  .
right - sided heart failure resulting from chronic hypertension in the pulmonary arteries and right ventricle .
a rapid heartrate that exceeds the range of the normal resting heartrate for age .
the presence of a stenosis  ( narrowing )  of the aortic valve .
the heart is located in the right hand sided hemithorax .
an abnormality of the mitral valve characterized by insufficiency or incompetence of the mitral valve resulting in retrograde leaking of blood through the mitral valve upon ventricular contraction .
any structural abnormality of a cardiac valve .
failure of the foramen ovale to seal postnatally ,  leaving a potential conduit between the left and right cardiac atria .
increased time between the start of the q wave and the end of the t wave as measured by the electrocardiogram  ( ekg )  .
necrosis of the myocardium caused by an obstruction of the blood supply to the heart and often associated with chest pain ,  shortness of breath ,  palpitations ,  and anxiety as well as characteristic ekg findings and elevation of serum markers including creatine kinase - mb fraction and troponin .
an insufficiency of the aortic valve ,  leading to regurgitation  ( backward flow )  of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle .
a single arterial trunk arises from the cardiac mass .
a slower than normal heart rate  ( in adults ,  slower than 60 beats per minute )  .
uncontrolled contractions of muscles fibers in the left ventricle not producing contraction of the left ventricle .
a type of ventricular tachycardia characterized by polymorphioc qrs complexes that change in amplitue and cycle length ,  and thus have the appearance of oscillating around the baseline in the ekg .
in this case the right ventricle is more muscular than normal ,  causing a characteristic boot - shaped  ( coeur - en - sabot )  appearance as seen on anterior -  posterior chest x - rays .
a complex congenital heart defect in which the aorta arises from the morphologic right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arises from the morphologic left ventricle .
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with an asymmetrical pattern of hypertrophy ,  with a predilection for the interventricular septum and myocyte disarray .
an anomaly of the intra - atrial or intraventricular septum .
a congenital heart defect characteizred by a specific combination of heart defects with a common atrioventricular valve ,  primum atrial septal defect and inlet ventricular septal defect .
reduction of the diameter of the coronary arteries as the result of an accumulation of atheromatous plaques within the walls of the coronary arteries ,  which increases the risk of myocardial ischemia .
delayed or lack of conduction of atrial depolarizations through the atrioventricular node to the ventricles .
an abnormality of the aorta .
coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing or constriction of a segment of the aorta .
paroxysmal chest pain that occurs with exertion or stress and is related to myocardial ischemia .
a fixed form of obstruction to blood flow across the left - ventricular outflow tract related to stenosis  ( narrowing )  below the level of the aortic valve .
congenital malformation of the ventral wall with partial or total evisceration of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and through the defect in the ventral wall .
a kind of atrial septum defect arising from an enlarged foramen ovale ,  inadequate growth of the septum secundum ,  or excessive absorption of the septum primum .
myocardial fibrosis is characterized by dysregulated collagen turnover  ( increased synthesis predominates over unchanged or decreased degradation )  and excessive diffuse collagen accumulation in the interstitial and perivascular spaces as well as by phenotypically transformed fibroblasts ,  termed myofibroblasts .
bradycardia related to a mean resting sinus rate of less than 50 beats per minute .
a type of subvalvular aortic stenosis resulting from thickening of the musculature of the interventricular septum ,  which results in obstruction to blood flow through the left - ventricular outflow tract .
a type of supraventricular tachycardia in which the atria are the principal site of electrophysiologic disturbance .
pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system .
pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from the right side of the heart to the left .
an abrupt loss of heart function .
a left - right reversal  ( or  \ "mirror reflection \ " )  of the anatomical location of the major thoracic and abdominal organs .
an abnormality of the pericardium ,  i .e . ,  of the fluid filled sac that surrounds the heart and the proximal ends of the aorta ,  vena cava ,  and the pulmonary artery .
accumulation of fluid within the pericardium .
rapid and unexpected death .
irreversible damage to heart tissue  ( myocardium )  due to lack of oxygen after a heart attack  ( myocardial infarction )  .
inflammation of the sac - like covering around the heart  ( pericardium )  .
any structural anomaly of the tricuspid valve .
one or more of the leaflets  ( cusps )  of the tricuspid valve bulges back into the right atrium upon contraction of the right ventricle .
an obstruction to the forward flow of blood in the outflow tract of the right ventricle .
diffuse thickening of the ventricular endocardium and by associated myocardial dysfunction
an abnormality of the right ventricle of the heart .
reduced ability of the right ventricle to perform its function  ( to receive blood from the right atrium and to eject blood into the pulmonary artery )  ,  often leading to pitting peripheral edema ,  ascites ,  and hepatomegaly .
third - degree atrioventricular  ( av )  block  ( also referred to as complete heart block )  is the complete dissociation of the atria and the ventricles .
a congenital malformation of the outflow tract of the heart .
any structural abnormality of the left ventricle of the heart .
enlargement or increased size of the heart left ventricle .
an abnormality of a cardiac ventricle .
enlargement of the cardiac ventricular muscle tissue with increase in the width of the wall of the ventricle and loss of elasticity .
a disorder of the cardiac conduction system of the heart characterized by ventricular preexcitation due to the presence of an abnormal accessory atrioventricular electrical conduction pathway .
an accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in a coronary artery .
an abnormal narrowing of the orifice of the mitral valve .
double outlet right ventricle  ( dorv )  is a type of ventriculoarterial connection in which both great vessels arise entirely or predominantly from the right ventricle .
a form of heart failure characterized by elevated cardiac output .
restrictive left ventricular physiology is characterized by a pattern of ventricular filling in which increased stiffness of the myocardium causes ventricular pressure to rise precipitously with only small increases in volume ,  defined as restrictive ventricular physiology in the presence of normal or reduced diastolic volumes  ( of one or both ventricles )  ,  normal or reduced systolic volumes ,  and normal ventricular wall thickness .
a cerebrovascular accident  ( stroke )  that occurs because of thromboembolism .
a progressive form of hearing impairment .
an abnormality of the pancreas .
the presence of inflammation in the pancreas .
a congenital anomaly in which the pancreas completely  ( or sometimes incompletely )  encircles the second portion of duodenum and occasionally obstructs the more proximal duodenum .
a acute form of pancreatitis .
a cyst of the pancreas that possess a lining of mucous epithelium .
impaired function of the exocrine pancreas associated with a reduced ability to digest foods because of lack of digestive enzymes .
a structural anomaly of the nasopharynx .
the male foreskin cannot be fully retracted from the head of the penis .
reduced ability to pass air through the nasal cavity often leading to mouth breathing .
an abnormality of the spleen .
abnormal increased size of the spleen .
absence  ( aplasia )  of the spleen .
an accessory spleen is a round ,  iso - echogenic ,  homogenic and smooth structure and is seen as a normal variant mostly on the medial contour of the spleen ,  near the hilus or around the lower pole .
polysplenia is a congenital disease manifested by multiple small accessory spleens .
the presence of only one working lower chamber in the heart ,  usually with a virtual absence of the ventricular septum and usually present in conjunction with double inlet left or right ventricle .
an abnormality of the functioning of the vestibular apparatus .

a form of sensorineural hearing impairment that affects primarily the higher frequencies .
an abnormality of the skeleton of foot .
the presence of an unusually high plantar arch .
talipes equinovarus  ( also called clubfoot )  typically has four main components: inversion and adduction of the forefoot ;  inversion of the heel and hindfoot ;  equinus  ( limitation of extension )  of the ankle and subtalar joint ;  and internal rotation of the leg .
a foot where the longitudinal arch of the foot is in contact with the ground or floor when the individual is standing ;  or ,  in a patient lying supine ,  a foot where the arch is in contact with the surface of a flat board pressed against the sole of the foot by the examiner with a pressure similar to that expected from weight bearing ;  or ,  the height of the arch is reduced .
hyperextension of the metatarsal - phalangeal joint with hyperflexion of the proximal interphalangeal  ( pip )  joint .
a foot for which the measured width is above the 95th centile for age ;  or ,  a foot that appears disproportionately wide for its length .
webbing or fusion of the toes ,  involving soft parts only or including bone structure .
a contracture of the achilles tendon .
a deformity of foot and ankle in which the foot is bent down and outwards .

an abnormality of the birth process .
premature rupture of membranes  ( prom )  is a condition which occurs in pregnancy when the amniotic sac ruptures more than an hour before the onset of labor .

any structural abnormality of the pyramidal tract ,  whose chief element ,  the corticospinal tract ,  is the only direct connection between the brain and the spinal cord .
continuous involuntary sustained muscle contraction .
spasticity is manifested by increased stretch reflex which is intensified with movement velocity .
a type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to coordinate the movements required for normal walking .
bradykinesia literally means slow movement ,  and is used clinically to denote a slowness in the execution of movement  ( in contrast to hypokinesia ,  which is used to refer to slowness in the initiation of movement )  .
a bilateral tonic - clonic seizure is a seizure defined by a tonic  ( bilateral increased tone ,  lasting seconds to minutes )  and then a clonic  ( bilateral sustained rhythmic jerking )  phase .
a kind of ataxia that affects movements of the extremities .
a neurological condition related to lesions of the basal ganglia leading to typical abnormalities including akinesia  ( inability to initiate changes in activity and perform volitional movements rapidly and easily )  ,  muscular rigidity  ( continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement )  ,  chorea  ( widespread arrhythmic movements of a forcible ,  rapid ,  jerky ,  and restless nature )  ,  athetosis  ( inability to sustain the muscles of the fingers ,  toes ,  or other group of muscles in a fixed position )  ,  and akathisia  ( inability to remain motionless )  .
chorea  ( greek for 'dance' )  refers to widespread arrhythmic involuntary movements of a forcible ,  jerky and restless fashion .
lipofuscin ,  a generic term applied to autofluorescent lipopigment ,  is a mixture of protein and lipid that accumulates in most aging cells ,  particularly those involved in high lipid turnover  ( e .g . ,  the adrenal medulla )  or phagocytosis of other cell types  ( e g . ,  the retinal pigment epithelium or rpe ;  macrophage )  .
a type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to perform rapidly alternating movements ,  such as pronating and supinating his or her hand on the dorsum of the other hand as rapidly as possible .
migraine is a chronic neurological disorder characterized by episodic attacks of headache and associated symptoms .
a type of migraine in which there is an aura characterized by focal neurological phenomena that usually proceed ,  but may accompany or occur in the absence of ,  the headache .
truncal ataxia is a sign of ataxia characterized by instability of the trunk .
underdevelopment of the corpus callosum .
a type of kinetic tremor that occurs during target directed movement is called intention tremor .
repeated headache attacks lasting 4 - 72 h fulfilling at least two of the following criteria: 1 )  unilateral location ,  2 )  pulsating quality ,  3 )  moderate or severe pain intensity ,  and 4 )  aggravation by or causing avoidance of routine physical activity such as climbing stairs .
a neural tube defect characterized by sac - like protrusions of the brain and the membranes that cover it through openings in the skull .

an abnormality of the upper respiratory tract .
any structural anomaly of the lung .
inflammation of any part of the lung parenchyma .
a functional defect characterized by reduced total lung capacity  ( tlc )  not associated with abnormalities of expiratory airflow or airway resistance .
pulmonary hypertension is defined mean pulmonary artery pressure of 25mmhg or more and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 15mmhg or less when measured by right heart catheterisation at rest and in a supine position .
difficult or labored breathing .
difficulty in breathing .the physical presentation of respiratory distress is generally referred to as labored breathing ,  while the sensation of respiratory distress is called shortness of breath or dyspnea .
asthma is characterized by increased responsiveness of the tracheobronchial tree to multiple stimuli ,  leading to narrowing of the air passages with resultant dyspnea ,  cough ,  and wheezing .
increased susceptibility to aspiration pneumonia ,  defined as pneumonia due to breathing in foreign material ,  as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of aspiration pneumonia .
a developmental defect in the formation of pulmonary lobes .
inflammation of the pleura .
an abnormality of the pulmonary pleura ,  the thin ,  transparent membrane which covers the lungs and lines the inside of the chest walls .

abnormality of the cerebral ventricles .
an increase in size of the ventricular system of the brain .
atrophy of the cortex of the cerebrum .
a generalized non - motor  ( absence )  seizure is a type of a type of dialeptic seizure that is of electrographically generalized onset .
a generalized myoclonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by bilateral ,  sudden ,  brief  (  < 100 ms )  involuntary single or multiple contraction of muscles or muscle groups of variable topography  ( axial ,  proximal limb ,  distal )  .
polymicrogyria is a congenital malformation of the cerebral cortex characterized by abnormal cortical layering  ( lamination )  and an excessive number of small gyri  ( folds )  .
any structural anomaly that affects the upper motor neuron .
periodic spells of incoordination and imbalance ,  that is ,  episodes of ataxia typically lasting from 10 minutes to several hours or days . \ n
a cavity within the cerebral hemisphere ,  filled with cerebrospinal fluid ,  that communicates directly with the ventricular system .
status epilepticus is a type of prolonged seizure resulting either from the failure of the mechanisms responsible for seizure termination or from the initiation of mechanisms which lead to abnormally prolonged seizures  ( after time point t1 )  .
abnormality of the basal ganglia .
the presence of calcium deposition affecting one or more structures of the basal ganglia .
an abnormal gait pattern in which persons stand and walk with their feet spaced widely apart .
hemorrhage occurring between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater .
an abnormality of the spinal cord  ( myelon )  .
during normal embryological development ,  the spinal cord first occupies the entire length of the vertebral column but goes on to assume a position at the level of l1 due to differential growth of the conus medullaris and the vertebral column .
a dementia associated with degeneration of the frontotemporal lobe and clinically associated with personality and behavioral changes such as disinhibition ,  apathy ,  and lack of insight .

gliosis is the focal proliferation of glial cells in the central nervous system .
a tendency to fall or the inability to keep oneself from falling ;  imbalance .

white color  ( lack of pigmentation )  of the eyebrow .

meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum located in the distal ileum .

more pronounced paramedian peaks and median notch of the cupid's bow .
a focal clonic seizure is a type of focal motor seizure characterized by sustained rhythmic jerking ,  that is regularly repetitive .
an exaggerated startle reaction in response to a sudden unexpected visual or acoustic stimulus ,  or a quick movement near the face .
a form of dystonia characterized by episodes of dystonia  ( often hemidystonia or generalized )  lasting from minutes to hours .
an abnormality resulting from an anomaly of neuronal migration ,  i .e . ,  of the process by which neurons travel from their origin to their final position in the brain .
an abnormality of the autonomic nervous system .
weakness of all four limbs .
an abnormality resulting from a lesion of the sympathetic nervous system characterized by a combination of unilateral ptosis ,  miosis ,  and often ipsilateral hypohidrosis and conjunctival injection .
increase in size of the cisterna magna ,  one of three principal openings in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid and pia mater ,  located between the cerebellum and the dorsal surface of the medulla oblongata .
heterotopia or neuronal heterotopia are macroscopic clusters of misplaced neurons  ( gray matter )  ,  most often situated along the ventricular walls or within the subcortical white matter .
unlocalized atrophy of the brain with decreased total brain matter volume and increased ventricular size .
a lesser degree of hair pigmentation than would otherwise be expected .

inability to initiate changes in activity or movement and to perform ordinary volitional movements rapidly and easily .
a slow ,  continuous ,  involuntary writhing movement that prevents maintenance of a stable posture .
habitual flow of saliva out of the mouth .
arnold - chiari malformation consists of a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils and the medulla through the foramen magnum ,  sometimes causing hydrocephalus as a result of obstruction of csf outflow .
lack of physical coordination resulting in an abnormal tendency to drop items or bump into objects .
deterioration of the tissues of the lateral corticospinal tracts .
cephalgia ,  or pain sensed in various parts of the head ,  not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve .
an abnormal sensation of spinning while the body is actually stationary .
a resting tremor occurs when muscles are at rest and becomes less noticeable or disappears when the affected muscles are moved .
anencephaly is a developmental anomaly characterized by a fetus that has no calvarium ,  with a lack of most or all of the fetus' brain tissue .
a defect of development of the brain characterized by replacement of greater portions of the cerebral hemispheres and the corpus striatum by cerebrospinal fluid  ( csf )  and glial tissue .
excessive daytime sleepiness .
attacks of disabling daytime drowsiness and low alertness .
repeated episodes of headache with rapid onset ,  reaching a peak within minutes and of short duration  ( less than one hour )  with pain that is throbbing ,  pulsating ,  or bursting in quality .
loss of previously present motor  ( i .e . ,  movement )  abilities .
an anomaly of the vermis of cerebellum .
congenital absence of the vermis of cerebellum .
any structural abnormality of the caudate nucleus .
compression of the spinal cord in the cervical region ,  generally manifested by paresthesias and numbness ,  weakness ,  difficulty walking ,  abnormalities of coordination ,  and neck pain or stiffness .
moderate mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient  ( iq )  in the range of 35 - 49 .
a form of hydrocephalus characterized by enlarged cerebral ventricles and normal cerebrospinal fluid  ( csf )  pressure upon lumbar puncture .
a tremor present when the limbs are active ,  either when outstretched in a certain position or throughout a voluntary movement .

a type of focal - onset seizure in which awareness is preserved .
this term describes abnormality of the white matter of the cerebrum resulting from damage to the myelin sheaths of nerve cells .

reduced ability to walk  ( ambulate )  .

a febrile seizure is any type of seizure  ( most often a generalized tonic - clonic seizure )  occurring with fever  ( at least 38 degrees celsius )  but in the absence of central nervous system infection ,  severe metabolic disturbance or other alternative precipitant in children between the ages of 3 months and 6 years .
abnormally diminished motor activity .in contrast to paralysis ,  hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength ,  but rather by a poverty of movement .
loss of developmental skills ,  as manifested by loss of developmental milestones .
an unintentional ,  oscillating to - and - fro muscle movement affecting the hand .
fasciculations are observed as small ,  local ,  involuntary muscle contractions  ( twitching )  visible under the skin .
an acquired language impairment of some or all of the abilities to produce or comprehend speech and to read or write .
focal impaired awareness seizure  ( or focal seizure with impaired or lost awareness )  is a type of focal - onset seizure characterized by some degree  ( which may be partial )  of impairment of the person's awareness of themselves or their surroundings at any point during the seizure .
weakness or partial paralysis in the lower limbs .
if the two laminae of the septum pellucidum are not fused then a fluid - filled space or cavum is present .
the presence of complexes of repetitive spikes and waves in eeg .
a type of rigidity in which a muscle responds with cogwheellike jerks to the use of constant force in bending the limb  ( i .e . ,  it gives way in little ,  repeated jerks when the muscle is passively stretched )  .
no consensus exists on what a stroke - like episode is ,  but these episodes can be functionally defined as a new neurological deficit ,  occurring with or without the context of seizures ,  which last longer than 24 hours .

loss  ( reduction of previously present )  of subcutaneous adipose tissue in the region of the trunk .
the presence of an abnormally increased amount of subcutaneous adipose tissue in the trunk of the body .
underdevelopment of the musculature .
underdevelopment of the biceps muscle .
underdevelopment of the serratus anterior muscle ,  which is involved in abduction ,  upward rotation ,  and elevation of the scapula .
underdevelopment of muscles of the arm .
loss  ( reduction of previously present )  of subcutaneous adipose tissue in the gluteal region .
an abnormally increased tendency towards muscle fatigue induced by physical exercise .
decreased strength of the abdominal musculature .
the presence of an abnormally increased amount of connective tissue .
underdevelopment of the latissimus dorsi muscle ,  which is involved in adduction ,  extension ,  internal rotation ,  and transverse extension of the shoulder and assists in movement of the scapula .
weakness of the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot ,  that is ,  of the movement of the toes towards the shin .
generalized weakness of the muscles of the arms and legs .
atrophy of the muscles of the ankle .
severe hypertrophy  ( increase in size )  of muscle cells .
rhabdomyolysis induced by exercise .
reduced ability to run .
atrophy of the peroneous muscles ,  peroneus longus  ( also known as fibularis longus )  ,  peroneus brevis  ( also known as fibularis brevis ,  and peroneus tertius  ( also known as fibularis tertius )  .
muscular atrophy involving the quadriceps muscle .
an increased amount of glycogen in muscle tissue .
reduced strength of the distal musculature of the legs .
generalized  ( unlocalized )  atrophy affecting muscles of the limbs in both proximal and distal locations .
an abnormal accumulation of lipids in skeletal muscle .
atrophy of the muscles that are responsible for moving the scapula ,  which are the levator scapulae ,  the infraspinatus muscle ,  the teres major ,  the teres minor ,  and the supraspinatus muscle .
muscular hypotonia  ( abnormally low muscle tone )  affecting the musculature of the trunk and with onset in infancy .
progressively reduced strength of the distal musculature .
generalized degenerative changes of the fat tissue .
progressive spinal muscular atrophy ,  i .e . ,  muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem .
chronic muscle inflammation accompanied by muscle weakness .
decreased intensity of the achilles reflex  ( also known as the ankle jerk reflex )  ,  which can be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed .
lack of strength of the proximal muscles that becomes progressively more severe .
increased width of the alveolar ridges .
impairment in the physical production of speech sounds .
chronic accumulation and overgrowth of the fungus candida albicans on the mucous membranes of the mouth ,  generally manifested as associated with creamy white lesions on the tongue or inner cheeks ,  occasionally spreading to the gums ,  tonsils ,  palate or oropharynx .
cleft palate of the midline of the palate .
a cleft of the lip with overlying mucous membrane .
a type of malocclusion in which there is a gap between the anterior teeth  ( incisors )  .
absence or underdevelopment of the pubic bone .
abnormal ossification  ( bone tissue formation )  affecting the pubic bone ,  also known as the pubis .
an abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the bony pelvis .
interruption of the innervation of the diaphragm .
a congenital failure of muscular development of part or all of one or both hemidiaphragms ,  resulting in superior displacement of abdominal viscera and altered lung development .
congenital absence of the left half of the diaphragm .
a decrease in the strength of the diaphragm .
absence  ( due to failure to form )  or underdevelopment of one or more components of the skeleton .
absence or underdevelopment of the maxilla .
absence or underdevelopment of the mandible .
absence or underdevelopment of frontal sinus .
absence or underdevelopment of a cranial sinus or sinuses .
an abnormality of the axial skeleton ,  which comprises the skull ,  the vertebral column ,  the ribs and the sternum .
absence  ( due to failure to form )  or underdevelopment of bones of the axial skeleton .
an abnormality of adipose tissue ,  which is loose connective tissue composed of adipocytes .
degenerative changes of the fat tissue .
an increase in adipose tissue mass by hyperplastic growth  ( increase in the number of adipocytes )  or by hypertrophic growth  ( increase in the size of adipocytes occurring primarily by lipid accumulation within the cell )  .
muscular atrophy involving the muscles of the upper limbs .
muscular atrophy involving the muscles of the hand .
a disease or lesion affecting the muscles of the thorax .
this term applies to all changes in bone mineral density of the tarsal bones ,  which  ( depending on severity )  can be seen on x - rays as a change in density and or structure of the bone .
an abnormal union between bones or parts of bones lower limbs .
any structural anomaly of a cerebral artery .

a structural abnormality of the interventricular septum .
in contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit  ( this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit )  is either located postaxial  ( on the fibular side of the foot ,  next top the little toe )  ,  preaxial  ( on the tibial side of the foot ,  next to the big toe )  or mesoaxial  ( somewhere central ,  between big and little toe )  ,  a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically ,  meaning anywhere else except post -  , meso -  or preaxial .
in contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit  ( this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit )  is either located postaxial  ( on the ulnar side of the hand ,  next to the little finger )  ,  preaxial  ( on the radial side of the hand ,  next to the thumb )  or mesoaxial  ( somewhere central ,  between thumb and little finger )  ,  a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically ,  meaning anywhere else except post -  , meso -  or preaxial .
a congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of supernumerary fingers or toes .
a bifid or bifurcated appearance of the femur as seen on x - rays ,  possible appearing as a more or less severe bowing of the upper leg .

pelvic asymmetry refers to asymmetric positioning of landmarks on the two sides of the pelvis and may have a structural or functional etiology .
the presence of osteophytes  ( bone spurs )  ,  i .e . ,  of bony projections originating from the acetabulum .
an exaggeration of the normal arched form of the acetabular roof such that it takes on a steep appearance .
an abnormality of the sacrosciatic notch ,  i .e . ,  the deep indentation in the posterior border of the hip bone at the point of union of the ilium and ischium .
hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia .
the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues either in the same or in opposite gonads .
abnormality of the female genital system .
abnormality of the male genital system .
aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the ovary .
aplasia ,  that is failure to develop ,  of the ovary .
a developmental disorder characterized by the progressive loss of primordial germ cells in the developing ovaries of an embryo ,  leading to hypoplastic ovaries composed of wavy connective tissue with occasional clumps of granulosa cells ,  and frequently mesonephric or hilar cells .
the onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls .
absence or underdevelopment of the testes .
testis not palpable in the scrotum or inguinal canal .
the presence of more than two testes .

an abnormality in the synthesis or catabolism of heme .

absence or underdevelopment of the urinary bladder .

the ability of the elbow joint to move beyond its normal range of motion .

the kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it .
the ability of the knee joint to extend beyond its normal range of motion  ( the lower leg is moved beyond a straight position with respect to the thigh )  .

palatal myoclonus is characterized by myoclonic  ( rhythmic involuntary jerky )  movements of the soft palate .
spinal myoclonus is generally due to a tumor ,  infection ,  injury ,  or degenerative process of the spinal cord ,  and is characterized by involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions ,  usually at a rate of more than one per second .
paroxysmal episodes of vertigo .
the combination of pendular nystagmus ,  head nodding ,  and torticollis .
a paroxysmal ,  transient loss of memory function with preservation of immediate recall and remote memory but with a severe impairment of memory for recent events and ability to retain new information .
